metadata.case_name: Konchada Ramamurti Subudhi (deceased) through LRs v. Gopinath Naik

facts.text: One Konchada Ramamurti Subudhi, deceased, represented by his legal representatives and appellants (Decree Holder), and Bhagirathi Naiko, represented by Gopinath Naik, Judgment Debtor, filed a compromise petition under O. XXIII, r. 3 of the Code of Civil Procedure in the Court of Subordinate Judge, Berhampur, in T.A. No. 13 of 1955.
In terms of the compromise petition, a decree was passed.
The Decree Holder filed an application for execution of the decree.
The Judgment Debtor filed M.J.C. No. 220/60 under s. 47, C.P.C., in the Court of Munsif, Berhampur, objecting to the execution of the decree.
The Munsif, Berhampur, dismissed the Judgment Debtor's application.
The District Judge, Ganjam-Boudh, Berhampur, affirmed the Munsif's order.
The Orissa High Court in Miscellaneous Appeal No. 59 of 1961 allowed the appeal, set aside the District Judge's judgment dated September 23, 1963.
Terms of compromise: Defendant-respondent to vacate suit house on or before 1-7-1960 (five years); failing which plaintiff entitled to execute decree and recover possession.
Arrears of rent up to 30-6-55 paid Rs. 1,125.
Future rent from 1-7-55 at Rs. 50 per month by end of each month until delivery; Rs. 300 paid as deposit for six months rent adjusted towards last six months ending 1-7-1960.
If defendant fails to pay rent for any three consecutive months, plaintiff at liberty to adjust advance, evict without waiting till 1-7-1960 by executing decree, and realise accrued amount.
House fell to share of minor son Konchada Koteswarrao, for whom plaintiff is guardian.
Each party to bear own costs in both courts.
Facts in this case are not in dispute.

legal_issues.text: Whether the compromise decree created a lease or a licence. If a lease, the Judgment Debtor entitled to protection under Orissa House-Rent Control Act (Orissa Act XXXI of 1958).

petitioner_arguments.text: Intention of decree holder was only to give accommodation to judgment debtor, not to create a fresh tenancy, as he had filed suit to eject the judgment debtor.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Ramjibhai Virpal Shah v. G. M. Bhagat (AIR 1954 Bom. 370)

respondent_arguments.text: Compromise decree created a lease, not a licence.
Word 'rent' used; Rs. 300 paid as deposit for six months rent; long period of five years granted.

court_reasoning.text: Decisive consideration is intention of parties, ascertained from all relevant provisions. Exclusive possession not conclusive evidence of lease; if coupled with interest in property, it is lease.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cited M. N. Clubwala v. Fida Hussain Saheb and Associated Hotels of India Ltd. v. R. N. Kapur.

court_reasoning.text: Substance preferred to form; real test intention; if creates interest in property, lease; if permits use while possession with owner, licence; exclusive possession prima facie tenancy but can be negatived.
Decree holder brought suit for ejectment; difficult to impute intention to create fresh tenancy.
Word 'rent' not conclusive; in wider sense includes payment by licensee.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cited State of Punjab v. British India Corporation Ltd.

court_reasoning.text: Rs. 300 was security, adjusted only against last six months rent.
Clause enabling execution if fails to pay for three consecutive months shows no intention of landlord-tenant relationship.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cited Sumatibai Waman Kirlikar v. B. Shirgaonkar.

court_reasoning.text: Length of five years does not militate against licence, as compromise in appeal after loss in trial court.

holdings.text: The compromise deed did not create a lease; therefore, Judgment Debtor not a tenant within S. 2(5) of Orissa House-Rent Control Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ramjibhai Virpal Shah v. G. M. Bhagat
precedents_cited.relevance: Elaborately considered interpretation of compromise decrees and distinction between lease and licence.

precedents_cited.case_name: M. N. Clubwala v. Fida Hussain Saheb
precedents_cited.relevance: Intention of parties decisive; exclusive possession not conclusive.

precedents_cited.case_name: Associated Hotels of India Ltd. v. R. N. Kapur
precedents_cited.relevance: Propositions on distinguishing lease from licence.
Exclusive possession not always tenancy; payment of rent not decisive.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Punjab v. British India Corporation Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Meaning of 'rent' in wider and narrower sense.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sumatibai Waman Kirlikar v. B. Shirgaonkar
precedents_cited.relevance: Default clause in compromise shows no tenancy.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Compromise petition and objection to execution.

statutes_cited.name: Orissa House-Rent Control Act (Orissa Act XXXI of 1958)
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines 'tenant'; protection against ejectment if lease.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment of Orissa High Court set aside; judgment of District Judge restored. Judgment Debtor not entitled to protection under the Act as no lease created.
outcome.relief_granted: Execution of decree permitted; appellants entitled to possession.
outcome.costs: Appellants to have costs incurred in Supreme Court.

key_quotes.text: Whether an agreement creates between the parties the relationship of landlord and tenant or merely that of licensor and licensee the decisive consideration is the intention of the parties.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle from M. N. Clubwala case.

key_quotes.text: The following propositions may, therefore, be taken as well-established: 1. To ascertain whether a document creates a licence or lease, the substance of the document must be preferred to the form...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Summary of tests from Associated Hotels.

key_quotes.text: This, it seems to us, shows that the intention of the parties was not to enter into the relationship, of a landlord and tenant.
key_quotes.speaker: court
